title: The empirical structure of psychopathology is represented in large language models
abstract: Abstract Background: Clinical assessment and scientific research in psychiatry is largely based on questionnaires that are employed to detect and quantify psychopathology. The development of large language models offers a new perspective for the analysis of the language and terminology that these questionnaires are based on. Methods: In the present study, we employed state-of-the-art large language models to derive numerical representations (so called â€˜text embeddingsâ€™) of semantic and sentiment content of items from established questionnaires for the assessment of psychopathology. We compared the pairwise associations between empirical data and text embeddings in order to test if the empirical structure of psychopathology can be reconstructed by large language models. Results: Across four large-scale data sets (n=1555, n=1099, n=11807, n=39755), we found a range of significant correlations between empirical item-pair associations and associations derived from text embeddings (r=0.18 to r=0.57, all p<0.05). Machine learning models based on semantic or sentiment embeddings predicted empirical item-pair associations with moderate to high accuracy (r=0.33 to r=0.81, all p<0.05). Similarly, empirical clustering of items and the grouping to established subdomain scores could be partly reconstructed by text embeddings. Conclusion: The present results demonstrate that large language models are able to represent substantial components of the empirical structure of psychopathology. Consequently, the integration of large language models into mental health research holds the potential to unlock numerous promising avenues. These may encompass improving the process of generating novel questionnaires, optimising generalizability and redundancy of existing questionnaires or facilitating the development of novel conceptualizations of mental disorders.

Joseph Kambeitz1,JasonSchiffman 2,LanaKambeitz-Ilankovic 1,3,Ulrich Ettinger4,Kai

Abstract:
Background: Clinical assessment and scientific research in psychiatry is largely based on
questionnaires that are employed to detect and quantifypsychopathology.The development
of large language models offers a new perspective for the analysis of the language and
terminologythatthesequestionnairesarebasedon.
Methods: In thepresentstudy,we employedstate-of-the-art large languagemodelstoderive
numerical representations (so called â€˜text embeddingsâ€™) of semantic and sentiment content
of items from established questionnaires for the assessment of ps ychopathology. We
compared the pairwise associations betweenempirical dataandtextembeddingsinorder to
test if the empirical structure of psychopathology can be reconstructed by large language
models.
Results:Acrossfour large-scaledatasets(n=1555,n=1099,n= 11807,n=39755),wefounda
range of significant correlations between empirical item-pair associations and associations
derived from text embeddings(r=0.18 tor=0.57,all p<0.05).Machinelearningmodelsbased
on semantic or sentiment embeddings predicted empirical item-pair a ssociations with
moderate to high accuracy (r=0.33 to r=0.81, all p<0.05). Similarly, empirical clustering of
items and the grouping to established subdomain scores could be partly reconstructed by
textembeddings.
Conclusion: The present results demonstrate that large language models are able to
represent substantial components of the empirical structure o f psychopathology.
Consequently, the integration of large language models into mentalhealth research holds
the potential to unlock numerous promising avenues. These may encompass improving the
process of generating novel questionnaires, optimising generalizability and redundancy of
existing questionnaires or facilitating the development of novel conceptualizations ofmental
disorders.
1
Introduction
The study of psychopathology holds great significance within psychiatric research as it
serves as the foundation for diagnostics, the identification of therapeutic targets, and the
assessment of mental health outcomes. Language serves as the primary medium for
conveying psychopathological descriptions of both inner experien ces and observable
behaviour. Thus, empirical studies typically assess psychopatholo gy with the help of
questionnaires that detect and quantify psychopathological phenomena such as changes in
perception, thought, emotion, behaviour including language and social interaction.Here,we
propose a novel approach utilising recently developed large language models (LLMs) (1â€“3)
to investigate structure and content of a range of clinical questionnaires. By analysing the
language used to describe symptoms and syndromes therein, this data-driven approach
offers an innovative perspective on psychopathology. Employing LLMs alongside empirical
data has the potential to focus the process of questionnaire gen eration by efficiently
identifying redundant items. Moreover, this integration may improve generalizability across
diverse populations, enable intercultural comparisons, and provide insights into the cultural
influencesonpsychopathology.
LLMs, rooted in deep-learning techniques, representadvancedartificial intelligencesystems
capable of processing and generating text (4). Typically, these models undergo training
using vast corpora comprising billions of words. Most recent LLMs were built based on a
specific architecture called â€˜transformerâ€™ (5). This allows for efficient model training due toa
self-attention mechanismthatcan weighthe importanceofdiffere ntwordsinasequence(5).
Current popular models such as GPT-3 (3), BERT (1) or T5 (6) havedemonstrated high
performance across a wider range of tasks encompassing languag e translation, text
summarizationand question answering,among others.
Interestingly, recent research indicates that LLMs can provide information regarding the
semantics of text and thus have been suggested to represent substantial aspects of our
knowledge about the world (7). Words can be represented by multidimensional vectors
(â€˜embeddingsâ€™) and the semantic similarity of two words can be quantified by the distance
between their vectors (7). It could be shown that similarity judgments derived from word
embeddings, closely resemble the similarity judgements of human raters (8,9). Moreover,
similarity regarding specific attributes of objects or animals(e.g.size,colour)(9) or similarity
of emotions (10) can bederivedfromLLMs,too.Finally,ithasbeend emonstrated thatLLMs
can detect the emotional content (â€˜sentimentâ€™) and provide not only coarse-grained (e.g.
positivevs.negative),butalso fine-grainedemotional character izationsoftext(11).
What is common to all approaches of psychological assessments is that questionnaires
include verbal descriptions of symptoms (e.g.â€œIfeltsad anddepressedâ€).In clinical practice,
weobserve thatsome symptomscommonlyco-occur whereasothe rsdonot.Theanalysisof
such associations and the details of this low-dimensional structurein dataacquiredwiththe
help of questionnaires is at the core of psychiatric research (12). As an example,
factor-analytic approaches suggestlatenttraitsthatgive rise topositive correlationsbetween
symptoms. Similarly, unsupervised machine-learning techniques such as clustering can
identify groups of patients (12) or symptoms that frequently co- occur (13). This
low-dimensional structure is the empirical basis for psychiatric syndromes, diagnoses or
more complex taxonomies of psychopathology (14). An alternativeapproachfocusesonthe
2
mutual interactions between symptoms and conceptualises psychopathology in network
models(15).
Interestingly, little is known about how empirical associations in psyc hopathology are
affected by the way clinical questionnaires are constructed. As an example, the specific
wording of questionnaire items is critical for the accuracy of the as sessment and all
subsequent interpretations. Even in the case of depressivedisorders,questionnairesfor the
assessment of symptoms show surprisingly little overlap in content (16).Thisisproblematic
as inconsistent research findings might result from differences be tween patients with
depression or - alternatively- fromdifferencesbetweenquestionnairesfor theassessmentof
depression. Moreover, it has been argued that two questionnaireitems might correlate
simply due to their semantic similarity (e.g. thesimilarityofthewaytheitemsareformulated
is similar) (17,18). Already over 150 years ago, Galton observed the strong ties between
language and psychological constructs and formulated the lexical hypothesis (19). This
suggests that the efficient description of thought and behaviour is highly relevant for
successful communication and thus, specific descriptions of personality traits will become
part of a groupâ€™s vocabulary. As an example, consider a person that â€œis pacing around the
room with an intense and restless energyâ€ and a person that â€œis fidgeting nervously and is
unable to sit stillâ€. A clinical psychiatristmightstate thatthesebehavioursaresimilar asthey
frequently co-occur. Thus, both patients might be described as â€œagitatedâ€. However, this
abstraction can be influenced by implicit assumptions of the psychiat rist (e.g. the
psychiatristâ€™s belief that these behaviours co-occur). Thus, it hasbeenarguedthatempirical
findings regarding psychological constructs represent aspects of the assessing clinician
rather thantheassessed individual (20,21).
These limitations indicate an urgent need for a rigorous and systematic investigation of
language employed for the description of psychopathology and its r elevance for the
interpretation of empirical findings and the structure of psychological constructs in the
context of mental health. In the presentwork,webuildup ontheseideasandaddressthese
pressing issuesbyapplyingLLMstotheanalysisofpsychopathology -relatedquestionnaires.
Previous results demonstrate how LLMs allow for the data-driven in vestigation of
psychological constructs (22,23) by characterising the semantics of various questionnaires
(24). In such models words can be represented by multidimensionalvectors (â€˜embeddingsâ€™)
and the semantic similarity of two words can be quantified by the distance between their
vectors (7). Cutler and Condon applied a similar approach to study empirical ratings from
personality questionnaires (24). In their study pairwise similarities o f adjectives were
extracted from LLMs. The correlational structure of these similarities corresponded strongly
to ratings from empirical data. Some early work has explored the potential of LLMs to
investigate overlap between scales (25) or between constructs (26). While initial studies
exist in the area of personality assessment (27,28) or emotion (10), the analysis of the
semantic properties ofclinical questionnairesusingLLMshasnotye tbeenappliedtomental
health and psychopathology. Thus, we studied four large-scale data sets to systematically
explore to which extent the empirical low-dimensional structure of psychopathology is
represented in these models. To this aim, we extracted pairwise similarities of established
questionnaireitemsfromlanguagemodelsandpredicted association sinempirical data.
Methods
3
Investigated questionnaires for the assessment of psychopathology
We investigated four questionnaires: the Depression-Anxiety-Stress Scale (DASS) (29), the
short form of the Oxford-Liverpool Inventory of FeelingsandExperiences(O-LIFE),the brief
version of the Prodromal Questionnaire (PQB) (30) and theAutismSpectrumQuotient(AQ)
(31). These scales cover a wider range of symptoms including depre ssion, anxiety,
schizotypal and attenuated psychosis-symptoms and the symptoms associated with autism
spectrum disorder. Moreover, the questionnairesrangefromscalesthatarebroadlyusedfor
the assessment of manifest and sometimes severe clinical symptoms (DASS, AQ) but also
scales that assess mild or moderate symptoms and traits that mightoccur in the healthy
population or individuals at-risk for psychiatric disorders (O-LIFE, PQB). For each
questionnaire,weanalysedempirical datafromlarge cohorts(see Table1).
The DASS includes 42 self-reported items (e.g. â€œI found myself getting upset by quitetrivial
thingsâ€) from 3 subdomains that are rated on a Likert scale with four levels. We used a
publicly available data set consisting of n=39755 participants
(
https://openpsychometrics.org/_rawdata/,retrieved 1stofJune2022).
The short form of the O-LIFE includes 43 self-reported items (e.g. â€œDoes a passing thought
ever seemsoreal itfrightensyou?â€) from4 subdomainsthatarer atedon abinaryscale(yes
vs.no).Weusedapubliclyavailabledatasetconsistingofn=11807pa rticipants(32).
The PQB (Prodromal Questionnaire- BriefVersion) includes21 self-reporteditems(e.g.â€œDo
familiar surroundings sometimes seem strange, confusing, threatening or unreal to you?â€)
from 4 subdomains (33) that are used to assess psychosis-risk symptoms. Items are rated
on a binary scale (true vs. false) and for each item the resulting distress is rated (distress
was not analysed in the present analysis). We analysed a sample of n=1099 healthy
individualsfroman undergraduatepopulation(34).
The AQ is based on 50 self-reported items (3 subdomains) to measure the expression of
autistic traits in individuals (e.g. â€œWhen Iâ€™m reading a story, I find it difficult to work out the
charactersâ€™ intentions.â€) which are rated on a Likert scale with four levels (Definitely Agree,
Slightly Agree, Slightly Disagree, Definitely Disagree). In the present analysis, we include
scores from n=1555 individuals presenting at the diagnostic assessment service for autism
at the Department of Psychiatry and Psychotherapy at the University Hospital in Cologne
(Germany).

Table 1:Overviewoftheempirical samplesinvestigated.
Embedding of questionnaire items using large language models
We employed the state-of-the-art LLMROBERTA (Robustly Optimized BERT Pretraining
Approach), which is provided by HuggingFace
(https://huggingface.co/T-Systems-onsite/cross-en-de-roberta-sentence-transformer). The
ROBERTA model follows a transformer-based architecture, cons isting of a stack of
transformer layers. It is trained on a large text corpus (approximately 2.5 TB) using the
objectives of predicting masked words or thenextsentence.Thistrainingenablesthemodel
to incorporate contextual information and generate text embeddings that capture semantic
meaning. One notable advantage of the ROBERTA model used in this study is that it has
been fine-tuned through multilingual training, specifically on combined samples in English
and German. As a result, the model can generate similar sentence embeddings for both
languages(35).
For each itemineach questionnaire,theROBERTAmodel can providean embeddingvector
with the dimension 1x768. The semantic similarity between two questionnaire items was
calculated as the cosine distance between their embedding vectors(fromnowonreferredto
as semantic embedding, seeFigure1)(8).Inaparallel analysis,wederivedsentiment-based
similarity for eachpair ofquestionnaireitems.Tothisaim,weemployed a setofprobewords
that captured distinct categories of self-reported emotional experience. As probe words we
selected 27 terms that have been identified in a previous study ('admiration', 'adoration',
'aesthetic appreciation', 'amusement', 'anger', 'anxiety', 'awe', 'awkwardness', 'boredom',
'calmness', 'confusion', 'craving', 'disgust', 'empathetic pain', 'entrancement', 'excitement',
'fear', 'horror', 'interest', 'joy', 'nostalgia', 'relief', 'romance', 'sadness', 'satisfaction', 'sexual
desire', 'surprise') (36). For each of these probe words, we derived a 1x384 dimensional
embedding vector using ROBERTA. Then, for each questionnaire item we calculated its
similarity to each probe word based on the cosinedistanceofbothembeddingvectors.This
provided a â€˜sentiment profileâ€™ for each questionnaire item with 27 values representing the
relevance of sentiment dimensions (from now on referred to as thesentiment embedding,
seeFigure 1).
5
Structure of psychopathology: item-pair associations and item clustering
In the present work, we investigated two complementary aspects of the structure of
psychopathology. First, we investigated pairwise associations of questionnaire items in
empirical dataandtestediftheseassociationscouldbepredictedb yembeddingvectors.For
a specific questionnaire, we first calculated the empirical correlations between each pair of
items. In a parallel procedure, the associations between pairs of questionnaire items were
estimated using (semantic and sentiment) embedding vectors and by using the cosine
similarity as a distance metric. We tested the degree to which empirica l item pair
associations related to associations in their (semantic andsentiment-based)embeddings by
linear regression analysis. Subsequently, we employed machine-lear ning to generate
models for the prediction of empirical pairwise item associations based onsemantic and
sentiment embeddings. Here, we implemented a random-forest regression (37) and tuned
the following hyperparameters: the maximum depth of each tree (between 2 and 10), the
ratio of candidate variables considered at each split (between 0.5 and 1.0), the number of
regression trees inthe ensemble(between 500and2000),thepro portionofrandomlydrawn
observations (between 0.5 and 1.0) (38).Hyperparameter tuning wasembeddedinanested
cross-validation scheme with 5 folds in the inner and outer loop and the hyperparameter
spaces were explored by random search with 20 iterations at each step with the coefficient
of determination as the optimization target. Model performance in the outer loop was
aggregatedacrossfoldsto estimateaccuracyofpredictionsonu nseendata.
In a complementary analysis, we investigated the clustering of questionnaire items and the
degree to which this cluster structure could be replicated based on the embedding of
questionnaire items. First, we used k-means clustering to assign eachquestionnaireitemto
a varying number of clusters (k=2 to k=10) based on empirical data. The same procedure
was applied to (semantic and sentiment) embedding vectors to create clustering solutions.
Subsequently, the correspondence of the empirical clustering solution and the clustering
solution basedon embeddingswastested bycalculatingtheadjusted rand-index(39).

ð‘€ð‘Žð‘¥ð¼ð‘›ð‘‘ð‘’ð‘¥ âˆ’ ð¸ð‘¥ð‘ð‘’ð‘ð‘¡ð‘’ð‘‘ð¼ð‘›ð‘‘ð‘’ð‘¥
For two cluster solutionsX and Y, a is the number of observations that are in the same
cluster forX and Y and b is the number of observations that are in differentclustersinboth
clustering solutions. The variablesc and d represent the number of observationsthatarein
the same cluster for onecluster solutionbutin differentclustersfor theother cluster solution.
The adjusted rand-index corrects the rand index for the probability that two observations
show correspondence of their cluster assignments by chance. In brief, this measure
quantifies the degree to which two random items show similar cluster membership in two
different clustering solutions while controlling for the potential that two items occur in the
same cluster by chance. Thus, the adjusted rand-index is high if twoitems are assigned to
the same cluster in both clustering solutions or to two different clusters in both clustering
solutions.
6
Figure 1: Overview of the analytic workflow. For each questionnaire empiricaldata from
study samples were obtained. In parallel, semantic embeddings for eachquestionnaireitem
were derived from a state-of-the-art large language model (ROB ERTA). A sentiment
embedding was obtained by comparing the embedding of each questionnaire item with the
embeddingsofa setofemotional words.
Results
Representation of empirical item-pair associations in large languagemodels
Overall, embeddings-based associations correlated significantly with empirical associations
in all questionnaires (Figure 2) both in the semantic and sentiment domain except for
sentiment embeddings of autistic traits as measured by the AQ (p=0.162). Highest
correlations were found for semantic embeddings of depression, anxiety and stress
symptoms (r=0.57, p<0.001). Except for prodromal symptoms(PQB),semantic embeddings
show slightly stronger correspondence to empirical data (r between 0.18 and 0.57) than
sentiment embeddings(r between0.05and 0.38).
7

Figure 2:Empirical correlation coefficientsbetweenempirical item-pair associationsand
associationsbasedon semantic embedding(upper row) or basedonsentiment embedding
(lower row).Eachpointrepresentsapair oftwoquestionnaireitem s.Dottedlinesdepict
perfectcorrelationsofr=1,solidlinesdepictthe estimatedregres sion.
Table 1:Correlationanalysisoftheassociationbetweenempirical item-pair a ssociations
and item-pair associationbasedonsemantic embeddingor basedonsentiment embedding
for four separate questionnaires.
In a subsequent analysis, we trainedmachine-learningmodelsfor the predictionofempirical
item-pair associations based on either semantic or sentiment embeddings . For all
investigated questionnaires we obtained high correspondence bet ween predicted and
empirical item-pair associations for bothsemantic and sentiment embeddings(all p<0.001).
In this analysis, depression, anxiety and stress symptoms could be predicted with the
highest accuracy (r=0.8 for semantic, r=0.81 forsentiment embeddings). Overall,semantic
andsentiment embeddingsshowed similar prediction accuracyfor eachquestionnaire.
8

Figure 3: Correlation between empirical item pair association and the item pair association
predicted by a random-forest regression model based on semantic (upper row) and
sentiment embedding(lower row) for eachquestionnaire.Each pointrepresentsapair oftwo
questionnaire items. Dotted lines depict perfect correlations of r=1, solid lines depict the
estimated regression.
Representation of item clustering in large language models
For depression, anxiety and stress symptoms (DASS), for autism-related symptoms (AQ)
and for psychotic-likeexperiences(O-LIFE),therand-indexindic atedstrong correspondence
between item-clustering based on word embeddings and item-clustering basedonempirical
data (Figure 4A). For these three scales a clear pattern emerged: clustering based on
semantic embeddings showed the highest rand-index,sentiment embeddings and random
clustering showed rand-index values around zero (as expected).This patternwasobserved
over the range ofinvestigatedmodelscomprisingbetween2and10c lusters.For attenuated
psychosissymptoms(PQB),no clear pattern emergedandoverall comparablylowvaluesfor
the rand-indexwereobtained.
Replication of established subscales in large language models
For each of the investigated questionnaires, there exist establish ed subscales (or
â€˜subdomainsâ€™) which are indicative of more fine-grained psychopathological concepts. We
tested to which extent this previously established structure couldbe replicated using the
empirical data available in the context ofthe presentanalysis,embedding vectors(semantic
and sentiment embedding) and compared this to randomized data. K-means clusteringwas
conducted for all items. Agreement of this clustering with the established structure was
assessed by calculating the clustering error rate. The results indicated a similar pattern for
9

all four questionnaires with empirical data showing the strongest c orrespondence to
established subdomains (low clustering error rate, Figure 4B) and clustering based on
randomised data showing the lowest correspondence (high clustering error rate).Clustering
based onsemantic embeddingsshowed error rates thatwerecomparable toempirical data.
Sentiment embeddingsshowed intermediate error rates for the autistic symptoms (AQ) and
for schizotypal/psychosis-risk symptoms (O-LIFE) but higher er ror rates for prodromal
symptoms (PQB) and depression, stress and anxiety symptoms(DASS) (Figure4,Table3).
Semantic embeddings showed lower error rates thansentiment embeddings for all four
questionnaires(Table3).
Figure 4:(A) Clusteringconsensusasmeasured bythe adjustedrand-index representing

clusteringsolutionbased on semantic andsentiment embedding(k-meansclusteringwith
n=200repetitions).(B) Correspondence ofitemclustering based onsemantic embedding
withclusteringofitemsbasedonestablishedsubdomains.

Discussion
In the present work, we investigated the representation of the structure of psychopathology
in LLMs across a range of established clinical questionnaires. Our results indicate that the
empirical association between two questionnaire items can bepredictedbasedon sentence
embeddings in a LLM (ROBERTA) with low to moderate accuracy using simple regression
models (r=0.05 to r=0.57) and with moderate to high accuracy using machine-learning
(r=0.33 to r=0.81). Moreover, clustering of items based onsentence embeddings showed
correspondence not only to clustering based on empirical data but also to previously
established subdomains of the questionnaires. In general, these r esults indicate that
empirical correlations in clinical questionnaires can to a largeextentbe reconstructed solely
based onLLMs.
11

In particular, our findingsshowsome variabilitywhen comparingdifferentquestionnairesand
their related psychopathologies and embedding methods. The corr elational analysis
indicated that empirical correlations of item-pairs could be predicte d best for anxiety,
depression and schizotypal symptoms. Similar findings were obtaine d using
machine-learning. Interestingly, correlational analysis results depended on the type of
embeddings: we found a higher correspondence between correlations based on empirical
data and correlations based onembeddings whenusing semantic embeddingscomparedto
sentiment embeddings. However, a similar accuracy in both types was obtained when
employing machine-learning. This might indicate that not all dimensionsof thesentiment
embeddings carry distinctiveinformation andthatthe identificationofrelevant dimensionsby
the random forest algorithm might help to improve accuracy. Moreo ver, the superior
performance of machine-learningbasedmodelsmightindicatethat embeddings relateto the
empirical low-level structure in a non-linear way. Interestingly, the empirical correlations
between autistic symptoms as measured with the AQ, could be partlyreconstructed by
semantic embeddings but were much worse bysentiment embeddings. This pattern was
present in the linear analysis(semantic:r=0.81, sentiment:r=0.05) and themachine-learning
analysis (semantic: r=0.58, sentiment: r=0.33). Incontrast,thequestionnairesDASS,OLIFE
and PQB did not show this discrepancy betweensemantic and sentiment embedding. As
autism is associated with a high prevalence of alexithymia, it could be hypothesised that
patients with autism struggle to identify and describe emotions and therefore emotional
connotation of questionnaire items does not correspond to empirical data as strong as
semanticembedding(40).
Overall,clustering analysisindicatedresultsinlinewiththe analysisofp airwiseassociations.
Similar patterns were obtained when investigating symptoms related to anxiety and
depression, autism or schizotypal disorder. For all three questionnaires, the clustering
solution basedon semanticembeddingscorrespondedbesttothee mpirical clustering.
It might be speculated that our results point to a fundamental difference between semantic
and sentiment. The former is predominantly â€œworld-relatedâ€, objective and deterministic,
while the latter refers to â€œperson-relatedâ€ inner emotional states, which are inherently
subjective and probabilistic. This distinction parallels the dichotomy between â€˜thingsâ€™ and
â€˜personsâ€™ in the fields of psychiatry/psychology (41,42) and has gained recent attention due
to its association with underlying cerebral mechanisms(43).Thesubjective andprobabilistic
nature of internal emotional states might render sentiment embeddings less well suited to
representempirical dataofpsychopathological questionnaires.
Our findings are in accordance with previous publications indicating that word embeddings
from LLMs can encode the similarity of words (9), general medical knowledge(44),emotion
(10) and personality ratings (24). Here, we extend this line of research tothe fieldofaltered
states or deviances of inner experience covered by psychopathology. Even though the
present analysis mainly focussed on questionnaires that measure psychopathology, the
theory and methodology is applicable to psychological constructs in general including
cognitions,emotionsor attitudes(45).
In research relying on self-rating questionnaires, there is often little control regarding how
participants conduct their ratings.Shallower processingofthequestionnaireitemsduring the
rating might relyonthe meresemanticaspects.In contrast,deep erprocessingmightrequire
more mental effort and include the evaluation ofitemsinthecontextofoneâ€™sownbiography
or past experiences above and beyond the semantic information contained in the items.
12
Increasing fatigue due to lengthy questionnaires might facilitate shallower processing. A
strong correspondence of empirical data to semantic similarity scores (e.g. low manifest
validity),mightindicateshallowprocessing(27,46).
Questionnaire design guided by sentence embeddings:
There are many potential applications for text embeddings to facilitate research in mental
health (24). Typically, the first step in the construction of a clinical instrument is the
generation of questionnaire items which contain text-based descr iptions of
psychopathological phenomena or mental states experienced bypatients (e.g. thoughts,
emotions, intentions). It is common practice to reduce such sets of questionnaire items
based on preliminary data and statistical procedures by means of f actor-analysis or
item-response analysis. Importantly, the initial generation of questionnaire items is often
based on the idiosyncratic conceptualisation of individual researchers or psychiatrists, but
not on a hypothesis-generating approach usingqualitative data(e.g.contentanalysisoffree
patient interviews) inasystematicwayleadingto theabductionofhy potheses.Thisfirststep
of the conceptualization of a questionnaire can potentially influence the low-level
correlational structurewhichislater on identifiedusing thegenerated questionnaire.With the
application of LLMs, this step can be implemented more efficiently andcircumventpotential
subjective biases. As an example language-based models allow the inve stigation of
hundreds or thousands of questionnaire items, if necessary. Hence, a large number of
candidate items can be screened very efficiently and items with high similarity might be
considered redundant and be excluded. Moreover, sensitivity analysis can be conducted by
excludingindividual itemsandassessing theeffectonthecorrelatio nal structure.
Another important aspect is the data collection procedure which oc curs during the
generation of a clinical questionnaire. Typically, this is a costly process conducted in larger
populations in order to obtain representative samples. However, this process might fail to
include individuals from populations that are â€˜hard-to-reachâ€™ due to their geographical
location or socio-economic situation (47). This might limit the generaliz ability of the
developed questionnaires to specific subsets of the population (48). Moreover, for some
countries the generation of sufficient validation samples might be infeasible due to the high
costs. In general, the datawhichLLMsarebased onconsistsofte xtthatisunstructured and
does not take a specific corpus describing psychopathologically relevant experiences into
account. However, data is substantially larger (e.g. 160 GB in the case of ROBERTA,
https://huggingface.co/roberta-base) compared to empirical data sets of questionnaires and
covers a larger proportion of the population.Thus,combining empirical dataand information
from LLMs during the process of generating questionnaires, might improve the
generalizability to all parts of the population. Moreover, the present approach can easily be
adopted to investigate pairwise item correlations across questionnaires. Asanexample,the
semantic similarity between existing and new questionnaires can be quantified in order to
decrease redundancyin data gathering(25).Lastly,theapproa ch presented hereoffers new
options to study intercultural differences of psychopathology.Notably, there is evidencethat
psychological concepts such as emotions are shaped by the cultural context (49,50). Thus,
the analysis of psychopathology based on LLMs can provide a different angle on the
analysisofsuchcultural influences.
Methodological considerations:
13
It is important to consider that all presented findings depend on the datawhichwasusedto
generate the employed LLM.Thus,using adifferentdatabasemigh taffectthe resultsandall
potential biases present in the source data might be transferred to the sentence
embeddings. As an example, previous studies indicated that the frequency of a word in a
training corpus might affect the resulting embedding and measuressuch as word similarity
(51,52). Moreover, the model architecturewill influencethe subsequentanalysisofsentence
embeddings. Interestingly, recent advances allow for thesystematicinvestigation ofdifferent
corpora and e.g. Hugging Face (huggingface.co) provides access to a large number of
languagebased modelswhichcanbe queriedfor comparativeanalysis .
Another important future direction focuses on the procedures whichare employedtoextract
information from language models.Asanexample,thedimensionalityo fembeddingsaffects
the performance in downstream language tasks (53). In some cases, embeddings vectors
have been shown to contain a correlational structure, and removing this might improve the
expressiveness of the embeddings (54,55). Lastly, it has recently been suggested that
extracting information along dimensional axesofspecificproperties(e.g.large - small,hard-
soft) might provide embeddings that are highly relevant for the assessment of real data but
alsoprovide highlyinterpretable values(9).
Limitations:
It needs to be noted that the cohorts investigated in this study differ with respect to age,
gender, access (general, help-seeking population) or language (E nglish, German).
Moreover, the investigated questionnaires differ withrespecttomultiplefeaturessuch asthe
response format (binaryvs.Likert-scale) or thewayitemsarefo rmulatedmightinfluenceour
results. As an example, DASS and AQ use a first-person perspective (e.g. â€œI felt that I
wasâ€¦â€) whereas OLIFE and PQ are formulated from a second-person view (â€œDo you think
that you couldâ€¦â€). Despite this heterogeneity, our results indicate that LLM can represent
psychopathologyacrossarange ofdifferentsamplesandquestio nnaires.
Another important aspect of concern for our result is the potential bias present in language
models. Recent studies demonstrate that word embeddings are related to the cultural and
social context of the text corpus they are based on (56). Thus,word embeddings closely
track cultural and social contexts. Any potential bias present inthe training data, might
subsequently result in biases of word embeddings, e.g. towards min orities. Moreover,
language use might differ between males and females (23) and dependonage(57).Lastly,
the nuanced terminology developed in psychopathology to describethe inner experience of
patients is presumably not part of the trainingdata andhencenotatall or underrepresented
in LLMs. In general, inner experiences frequently take the form ofinner speech but might
also occur in experiences thataremore difficultto expressverballysuch asunusual sensory
experiences including hallucinations, feelings, inner images, thoughts including delusional
experiences, delusional mood or unsymbolized thinking (58). As a consequence, these
aspects of inner experiences are not adequately represented in LLMs and thereforedifficult
to investigatewithapproachessuchas word embeddings.
Conclusion:
In summary, we provide evidence for the representation of the st ructural aspects of
psychopathology in LLMs. These initial resultsmotivatefurther investigationsofthepotential
14
of extracting information from such models to foster innovative research in mental health.
Potential applications include the generation of novel questionnaires guided by LLMs, the
generation of statistical priors in the investigation of psychologica l concepts and the
assessmentofpsychopathologyin aspecificcontext(e.g.hard- to-reach populations)(24).
